Solve Joint ODE System

Source: R/utils.R
dot-solve_joint_ode.Rd

Solves the ODE system governing biomarker trajectories and cumulative hazard in joint models. Computes dynamics without random effects for efficiency, which are added post-computation.

Usage

.solve_joint_ode(params, initial = c(0, 0, 0))

Arguments

params

A list containing all necessary model components:

data

Subject-specific data with components:

  • time: Event/censoring time

  • status: Event indicator (0/1)

  • covariates: Baseline covariates for survival model

  • longitudinal: List with times, measurements, covariates

coef

Model coefficients:

  • baseline: B-spline coefficients for baseline hazard

  • hazard: Coefficients \([\alpha_m, \alpha_{\dot{m}}, \alpha_{\ddot{m}},\) \(\phi_1, ..., \phi_p]\)

  • index_g: B-spline coefficients for g(u) function

  • index_beta: Single index coefficients \([\beta_m, \beta_{\dot{m}}, \beta_X, \beta_t]\)

config

Spline configurations:

  • baseline: Config for baseline hazard B-splines

  • index: Config for single index model B-splines

initial

Initial conditions \([\Lambda(0), m(0), \dot{m}(0)]\). Default is c(0, 0, 0).

Value

A list containing the ODE solution with components:

cum_hazard

Cumulative hazard \(\Lambda(T)\) at event time (without exp(b))

log_hazard

Log-hazard \(\log(\lambda(T))\) at event time (WITHOUT b term)

biomarker

Vector of biomarker values \(m(t)\) at observation times (WITHOUT b shift). NULL if no longitudinal observations exist.

Details

The ODE system is: $$ \frac{d}{dt}\begin{pmatrix}\Lambda \\ m \\ \dot{m}\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda(t) \\ \dot{m} \\ g(\beta^T Z) \end{pmatrix} $$

where:

  • \(\Lambda(t)\) is the cumulative hazard function

  • \(m(t)\) is the biomarker trajectory

  • \(\dot{m}(t)\) is the biomarker velocity (first derivative)

  • \(\lambda(t) = \exp[\eta^T B_\lambda(t) + \alpha_m m(t) +\) \(\alpha_{\dot{m}} \dot{m}(t) + \alpha_{\ddot{m}} \ddot{m}(t) +\) \(W^T\phi]\) is the hazard function

  • \(g(u) = \theta^T B_g(u)\) is the flexible acceleration function

  • \(u = \beta^T Z\) is the single index with \(Z = [m, \dot{m}, X_{long}, t]\)

  • \(B_\lambda(t)\) and \(B_g(u)\) are B-spline basis functions

The random effect \(b_i\) represents subject-specific deviation and is excluded from the ODE for computational efficiency. To incorporate \(b_i\):

  • Actual log-hazard: log_hazard + b

  • Actual cumulative hazard: Lambda * exp(b)

  • Actual biomarker for likelihood: biomarker + b

This separation is mathematically valid because \(b_i\) enters as an additive constant in the log-hazard, yielding: \(\Lambda(t|b) = e^b \Lambda(t|0)\). The ODE solver uses adaptive step size control (LSODA method) for numerical stability.

See also

JointODE for the main model fitting function

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Example: Solve ODE for a subject
params <- list(
  data = subject_data,  # Subject-specific data
  coef = list(
    baseline = c(0.1, 0.2, 0.15),     # Baseline hazard spline coefficients
    hazard = c(0.3, 0.1, 0.05, 0.2),  # Hazard coefficients
    index_g = c(0.5, 0.3, 0.2),       # Acceleration function coefficients
    index_beta = c(0.4, 0.2, 0.1, 0.15) # Single index coefficients
  ),
  config = list(
    baseline = baseline_spline_config,
    index = index_spline_config
  )
)

# Solve the ODE system
sol <- .solve_joint_ode(params)

# Incorporate random effect b_i = 0.5
b <- 0.5
actual_log_hazard <- sol$log_hazard + b
actual_cum_hazard <- sol$cum_hazard * exp(b)
predicted_biomarker <- sol$biomarker + b  # Add b to biomarker values
} # }
